revision.text:
{|{{Infobox Aircraft Begin |name = P.B.31 Nighthawk <!-- avoid stating manufacturer (it's stated 3 lines below) unless name used by other aircraft manufacturers --> |image = Supermarine P.B.31E Nighthawk.jpg<!--in the ''Image:filename'' format with no image tags--> |caption = Supermarine Nighthawk }}{{Infobox Aircraft Type |type = Anti-Zeppelin fighter |national origin = [[United Kingdom]] |manufacturer = [[Supermarine]] |designer = |first flight = 1917<!--If this hasn't happened, skip this field!--> |introduction = <!--Date the aircraft entered or will enter military or revenue service--> |retired = <!--Date the aircraft left service. If vague or more than a few dates, skip this --> |status = Prototype only |primary user = |more users = |produced = <!--Years in production (eg. 1970-1999) if still in active use but no longer built --> |number built = 1 |program cost = |unit cost = <!--Incremental or flyaway cost for military or retail price for commercial aircraft--> |developed from = [[Pemberton Billing P.B.29E]]<!--The aircraft which formed the basis for this aircraft--> |variants with their own articles = <!--Variants OF this aircraft--> }} |}
The '''P.B.31E Nighthawk''', the first project of the [[Noel Pemberton Billing|Pemberton-Billing]] operation after it became [[Supermarine Aviation Works Ltd.]], was a prototype anti-[[Zeppelin]] fighter with a crew of three to five and an intended endurance of 9–18 hours. It was first flown in February 1917 with Clifford Prodger at the controls.<ref name="mason fighter p60"/>
==Design and development== The Nighthawk had six-bay swept quadraplane wings and a [[biplane]] tailplane with twin fins and rudders. The fuselage filled the gap between the second and third wings; the cockpit, which carried up to the top wing "turret", was enclosed and heated.
Along with the intended long endurance, it was suggested it would be able to patrol at low speeds and await the Zeppelin.<ref>{{citation |journal=Flight |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1953/1953%20-%201306.html |title=Sires of the Switft |date=1953 |page=462}}</ref> For armament, it had a trainable nose-mounted [[searchlight]], a 1½-pounder (37 mm) [[recoilless rifle#History|Davis gun]] mounted above the top wing with 20 shells, and two .303 in (7.7 mm) [[Lewis gun]]s. Power for the searchlight was provided by an independent petrol engine-driven generator set made by [[ABC Motors]], possibly the first instance of a recognisable airborne [[auxiliary power unit]].<ref name="Andrews p21">Andrews and Morgan 1987, p. 21.</ref>
==Operational history==
Although touted as being able to reach 75 mph (121 km/h), the P.B.31E prototype only managed 60 mph (97 km/h) at 6,500 ft (1,981 m) and took an hour to climb to 10,000 ft (3,048 m), which was totally inadequate for intercepting Zeppelins.<ref name="Bruce p69">Bruce 1969, p. 69.</ref> Given the [[Anzani]] engine's reputation for unreliability and overheating, it is unlikely that the aircraft would have delivered the advertised endurance either.

|guns= One 1½-pdr Davis gun and one Lewis gun above upper wing, and one Lewis gun in the nose
